prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong here. The situation is about a couple where the guy is paying all the bills because his girlfriend only works part-time. Then there's an incident where he asks her to pay for a $40 takeout because he forgot his wallet, and she had a negative reaction. Now he's considering making her pay some bills because of this one incident.

First, I need to consider the dynamics of their relationship. The guy has been paying everything, maybe because he has a higher income. The girlfriend works part-time, so her income is lower. The issue here is that he's upset about her reaction to paying for the takeout, which he sees as a small amount. He feels that after this incident, she should start contributing more, even if it's just in principle.

Is the author in the wrong? Well, contributing to household expenses is a common topic in relationships. If both parties are contributing in some way, it's usually healthier. But in this case, the guy has been paying everything. The problem arises when he's using one incident to justify making her take on more financial responsibility. 

He mentions she works part-time. If her income is low, expecting her to cover a significant portion of bills might not be feasible. However, even a small contribution could be beneficial for both to share expenses. The key here is whether the author is being fair. The incident was a $40 takeout, which he might view as a test of her ability to contribute. But using a single event as the reason to change the financial arrangement could be seen as holding a grudge or overreacting. 

Also, the way he framed the question—making her start paying some bills over a single incident—might be the issue. It's possible he's using this as a way to address deeper feelings about fairness in the relationship. Maybe he's been paying everything and now feels it's time for her to contribute, even if it's not because of the takeout incident. However, using one incident as the catalyst could be seen as unfair, especially if her part-time job doesn't allow her to contribute much.

On the other hand, if he's been paying everything and she's not contributing at all, even a small amount could be a reasonable step. But the problem is that he's making it about a single incident rather than discussing a mutual agreement on splitting costs. The way he's approaching it might come across as punitive, which could damage the relationship. 

So, considering all that, the author might be in the wrong because he's using a single, minor incident to change the financial arrangement without considering her financial limitations or discussing it openly. It's important to have open communication about financial expectations rather than reacting to a specific event. Therefore, the answer would be A (Yes, the author is in the wrong).
